id_table_1.caption: ’s parameters and descriptions
table: Operation Params Description Tap x, y Simulates the human touch by selecting an element on the screen, used for choosing menu options or activating features. Text content Inputs a specified string into a text field on the interface, used for filling out forms or searching for information. Swipe x, y, direction Navigates through content or performs actions by swiping in a particular direction on the screen, such as switching pages. Read file, goal Reads the content of a specified document, such as PDFs or Word files, used for obtaining and analyzing information. think flow, goal Used during task execution to read from or write to working memory, assisting in decision-making and planning. Back none Returns to the previous interface, used for undoing actions or navigating to the previous screen. Home none Navigates back to the smartphone’s main screen, typically used to end the current session or access other applications. Wait none Chooses to wait when the current operation is unresponsive or loading, ensuring the system has adequate time to process. Stop none Ends the exploration of the current task when it is believed to be completed or no longer feasible.
references: HumanBasic Operation.            Emulating human behavior, we craft nine basic operations for the expert, known as HumanBasic Operations. These encompass basic smartphone interactions, such as: tapping (Tap), text entry (Text), swiping (Swipe), reverting (Back), navigating to the home screen (Home), and terminating an operation (Stop). These operations extend beyond facilitating basic interaction, they also emulate the processes of human cognition. The             Think            operation models human cognitive processes concerning short-term objectives. The             Read            operation facilitates processing extensive documents, while the             Wait            function ensures adaptability to the performance variations of different devices. Detailed operation parameters and descriptions are presented in the table                     1                   .

id_table_2.caption: Expert Eval: We developed 28 examples encompassing various complexity levels and application scenarios to comprehensively assess the performance of Device Operation Agent in practical applications.
table: Category Application Complexity Task Description Social Media Twitter C1 Open the messages on twitter and read the first unread message. C2 Post a tweet summarizing the recent discussions on twitter about LLM Based Agents. Instagram C1 Search for "lenovo" on Instagram. C2 Search for meme-related accounts on Instagram and post comments based on the content. Tiktok C1 Leave a comment on tiktok’s latest video. C2 Review the last ten videos on my TikTok feed trends and search for topics that might interest me. Xiaohongshu C1 Scroll through Xiaohongshu until you find a post that explains a trip to Miami, and then like it. C2 Find popular food in Miami and then create a collection album in Xiaohongshu. Online Service Google Maps C1 Navigate to Renmin University of China. C2 Find delicious Xinjiang cuisine near Renmin University of China and then navigate there. Alibaba C1 Enter Lenovo’s store in Temu. C2 Find the price of the latest Lenovo Legion model. Google Play C1 Download the JD (Jingdong) App from Google Play. C2 Download a popular note-taking software. Messenger C1 Check the latest verification code information. C2 Delete messages in the text that are unrelated to the verification code. Productivity Tool Notion C1 Create a new page in Notion. C2 Create a new note detailing your job duties and title it appropriately. Gmail C1 Write an email to {address}. C2 Go through the unread emails and draft a response based on their content. Google Chrome C1 Enter arxiv.org in Chrome. C2 Download the latest paper on LLM (Large Language Model) Based Agent from arXiv. Wikipedia C1 Open Wikipedia and search for "collective intelligence". C2 Create a Wikipedia page about yourself. Cross-App C2 Download {app_name} and complete account registration with my phone number. C3 Help me operate a twitter account with the theme {topic}. C3 Help me find {Product Name} that is popular and reasonably priced. C3 Help me explore how to use {app_name} and write a technical report-style document in Notion.
references: In order to comprehensively evaluate the ability of MobileExperts in handling diversified and complex tasks, we have constructed a new benchmark - Expert-eval. Based on this Benchmark, we compared our method with two baselines, and performed ablation experiments on various key modules of MobileExperts. Meanwhile, in order to intuitively display the performance of MobileExperts in tasks of different intelligence levels, we have carried out a case study to deeply analyze its behavior strategy and effect. Considering the requirement of overall action space for api accessibility, we chose to conduct these experiments on the Android system. The overall tasks included in Expert-Eval can be found in Table               2             .

references: In this experiment, we used a unified mobile device, pre-installed with all the necessary applications, and tested expert-eval on three methods. In order to ensure the consistency of the experimental results, we set the maximum number of automatic explorations for individual tasks of MobileExperts and AppAgent to 10 times, and required each method to try a maximum of three times, finally choosing the best results as the outcome. In addition, considering the importance of the process score, we set the maximum number of execution steps for all methods’s C1 and C2 Task to 15 steps to prevent cycle errors, ensuring the efficiency of the experiment and the reliability of the results. The results of the experiment are presented in table                  3                .
